title: R41249
content: Prior to 1996, health insurance coverage for mental illness was historically less generous than for physical illnesses, with lower limits, fewer covered services, and higher cost sharing. Mental health parity laws were enacted to address this disparity in insurance coverage. Mental health parity laws aim to reduce disparities in insurance coverage for mental health services compared to medical or surgical services. Policymakers have developed approaches that may mandate coverage for certain mental illnesses and require parity coverage. Mental health parity laws aim to reduce disparities in insurance coverage by mandating coverage for certain mental illnesses and requiring parity coverage. Approaches to achieving parity can be broadly categorized into three types: full parity approach, minimum mandated benefit approach, and mandated offering parity approach. Federal mental health parity law prior to the ACA employed a mandated offering parity approach. The ACA expands federal mental health parity requirements by mandating coverage for certain mental health and substance abuse disorder services. It also requires insurers to comply with parity requirements when covering both mental health and medical/surgical benefits. The MHPA (P.L. 104-204) was the first federal mental health parity law, mandating that annual and lifetime dollar limits on mental health coverage be no less than those for medical services. It applies to group health plans governed by ERISA, PHSA, and IRC, with a small employer exemption for those with 2-50 employees. The Mental Health Parity Act (MHPA) amends federal laws to apply parity coverage requirements to all group health plans, with exemptions for small employers and cost increases. MHPA was extended annually until 2008 and its sunset provision was repealed by the Mental Health Parity and Addiction Equity Act (MHPAEA), which expands the scope to include substance use disorders. The Mental Health Parity and Addiction Equity Act (MHPAEA) expands federal mental health parity requirements to include substance use disorders.
